title: 114_hr470
content: The "Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest Land Adjustment Act of 2015" allows for the disposal of isolated National Forest System land in Georgia to be used for more efficient purposes. Proceeds from land sales will be used by the Forest Service to acquire land for National Forest use in Georgia. The term "Secretary" in the Act refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The Secretary is authorized to sell or exchange United States' rights in National Forest System land in Georgia totaling 3,841 acres. Maps of the land are available for public inspection. The Secretary may modify boundaries based on land management considerations and convey land by quitclaim deed. Reservations may be made for management purposes or to protect the public interest. The Secretary may not sell or exchange land below market value. The Secretary may sell or exchange land under this Act at market value determined by appraisal or competitive bid. Appraisals must comply with federal standards and be approved by the Secretary. Consideration for sales or exchanges must be paid in cash. The Secretary may sell land at public or private sale, with consideration to be paid in cash. Cash equalization payments in excess of 25% of the land value may be accepted for exchanges. The sale may be conducted through competitive methods like auction or bid, as determined by the Secretary. Public or private solicitations may also be made. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange land through public or private solicitations, with the discretion to reject inadequate offers. Brokers or third parties can be used in the land disposition, with commissions or fees paid from sale proceeds. SEC. 4. TREATMENT OF PROCEEDS. The Secretary shall deposit sale proceeds in the fund established under Public Law 90-171. Amounts deposited shall be available for land acquisition in Georgia without further appropriation. Funds cannot be used to acquire land without owner consent.
